ImageContent.Description: The bison embodies a paradox: immense strength paired with quiet calm. Weighing up to 900 kilogrammes and standing  almost 2 metres tall, these giants roam North America's grasslands and river valleys in mobile herds. Photographed here in Yellowstone National Park, in Wyoming, United States, this herd represents the wild heart of American plains—a reminder of the strength that echoes across the world's wilderness, from the bison of the west to India's own gaur.
ImageContent.Headline: Herds of heritage
ImageContent.Title: Bison grazing at thermal hot springs, Yellowstone National Park, Wyoming, United States

ImageContent.Description: Centuries ago, in parts of ancient Europe, the night marking the end of the harvest and beginning of winter was feared as a time when the worlds of the living and the dead overlapped. Communities lit fires to keep wandering spirits at bay, believing that on this night the boundary between the two faded. These rituals gave rise to Halloween, echoing in legends around Bran Castle.
ImageContent.Headline: Legends in the mist
ImageContent.Title: Entrance of Bran Castle in Bran, Brașov, Romania
ImageContent.Copyright: © blue sky in my pocket/Getty Images

QuickFact.MainText: During World War II, Bran Castle was turned into a hospital for wounded soldiers by Princess Ileana, who was trained as a nurse.

ImageContent.Description: Every year during the Hindu lunar month of Kartik, the desert town of Pushkar in Rajasthan comes alive with one of the country's most colourful gatherings—the Pushkar Camel Fair, a highlight of the festive season. The event usually takes place between late October and early November and this year the celebrations stretch from today until 5 November, drawing crowds from near and far.
ImageContent.Headline: Hooves, hues and heritage
ImageContent.Title: Camels at Jaisalmer, Rajasthan, India

ImageContent.Description: The Portuguese island of Madeira—about 965 kilometres south-west of mainland Portugal—hides a forest unlike any other. On its northern slopes lies Fanal Forest, where veils of mist drift through centuries-old til trees. These are part of the Laurissilva of Madeira—an outstanding relict of a once widespread laurel forest type. Laurissilva is the largest surviving area of its kind, with about 90% considered primary forest. Home to a unique array of plants and animals, including endemic species such as the Madeiran long-toed pigeon, it remains a living museum of natural history.
ImageContent.Headline: Rooted in time
ImageContent.Title: Ancient til trees in Fanal Forest, island of Madeira, Portugal

ImageContent.Description: From 18th-century visitors to fire-carved trails, this rock city tells a story of survival. Hidden in Czechia's Hradec Králové Region, the Adršpach–Teplice Rocks form Central Europe's largest sandstone labyrinth. For centuries, the cliffs and passages lay cloaked in forest, until a great fire stripped the land bare. Arches, towers and winding corridors emerged out of the ashes, and the first hiking paths were carved into the rock. Soon after, explorers and poets left their marks with stone inscriptions that captured a destination both wild and enchanting.
ImageContent.Headline: A gateway to stone wonders
ImageContent.Title: The Gothic Gate in the Adršpach-Teplice Rocks, Czechia

ImageContent.Description: Today's image features Mumbai's Juhu Beach, where waves meet devotion as thousands gather for Chhath Puja, one of India's most ancient and rigorous festivals. Though rooted in Bihar, Jharkhand and eastern Uttar Pradesh, the tradition travels with communities, turning city shorelines into spaces of worship beneath the open sky. Chhath is dedicated to Surya, the Sun God, and his consort Usha, revered as Chhathi Maiya. Devotees fast, pray and thank the Sun God for sustaining life while seeking blessings for health, prosperity and children's well-being.
ImageContent.Headline: Chhath on the shore
ImageContent.Title: People worshipping the sun on Chhath, at Juhu Beach, Mumbai, Maharashtra

ImageContent.Description: Perched high in the mountains of Ethiopia, Eritrea and Somalia, the thick-billed raven holds the title of the world's largest raven. At more than 70 centimetres in length and weighing around 1.5 kilograms, it is about a quarter heavier than the common raven. Its enormous, arched bill—pale at the base and close to 9 centimetres long—is the largest among perching birds. These ravens live mostly between 1,500 and 3,400 metres above sea level, found across farmland, rocky cliffs and even rooftops in mountain towns.
ImageContent.Headline: Bigger, bolder, beakier
ImageContent.Title: Thick-billed raven, Simien Mountains, Ethiopia

QuickFact.MainText: Thick-billed ravens are native to northeastern Africa, found mainly in Eritrea, Somalia and Ethiopia.

ImageContent.Description: On Oregon's coast in the United States, Bandon greets visitors with salty air and the gentle clang of harbour bells. The town began as a small settlement in the 1850s and grew into a centre for timber and salmon fishing. Its maritime past endures in the restored Coquille River Lighthouse, whose beacon once guided ships safely to shore.
ImageContent.Headline: Rock stars of Bandon
ImageContent.Title: Sea stacks of Bandon Beach in Bandon, Oregon, United States

ImageContent.Description: They wait, motionless, on the edge of a frozen world. Photographed in Churchill, Canada, this polar bear rests along the shores of Hudson Bay, where bears gather each year for the return of the sea ice that allows them hunt seals again—their main source of food. For over a decade, Polar Bears International, a non-profit organisation, has streamed live footage of their movements, offering a rare gimpse into life balanced on the edge of a warming world.
ImageContent.Headline: The patience of a polar bear
ImageContent.Title: Polar bear in Churchill, Manitoba, Canada

ImageContent.Description: What would you wish for if a single lantern could carry it skyward? Tonight, in northern Thailand, the Yi Peng festival offers that chance. This centuries-old Lanna tradition celebrates the twelfth lunar month with glowing paper lanterns—khom loi—that are released to honour the Buddha. Each lantern is believed to carry away misfortune and light the way toward a brighter future. Children steady the lantern frames, elders whisper blessings and the crowd pauses as hundreds of lights drift higher than the trees. Farther south, the same full moon watches over Loy Krathong, a sister festival, where candlelit rafts glide across the water.
ImageContent.Headline: Sky full of wishes
ImageContent.Title: Colourful lanterns at the temple of Wat Phra That Hariphunchai, Lamphun, Thailand

ImageContent.Description: Glowing lamps, devotional music and shared meals—today we celebrate Guru Nanak Gurpurab, which marks the birth anniversary of Guru Nanak, the founder of Sikhism. The featured image shows the Golden Temple in Amritsar, where festivities unfold with splendour. As dawn settles over the marble walkways, pilgrims gather in reverent silence, their hymns rising through the cool November air. The temple's reflection shimmers across the 'sarovar,' the sacred pool that surrounds it; by night it glows against the dark sky as celebrations reach their peak. Rooted in 15th-century Punjab, this festival embodies Guru Nanak's enduring message of unity and compassion. Observed on Kartik Purnima, the full moon day of Kartik in the Nanakshahi calendar, the date shifts each year in the Gregorian calendar, usually falling in November.
ImageContent.Headline: Celebrating Guru Nanak Gurpurab
ImageContent.Title: Golden Temple, Amritsar, Punjab, India

ImageContent.Description: Some bridges connect two sides. Tower Bridge connects history, engineering and a flair for drama. Standing next to the Tower of London and rising over the River Thames since 1894, this London icon knows how to lift spirits—and traffic. With its twin towers, blue-and-white paintwork and bascules that open like a giant's drawbridge, Tower Bridge is less a traffic solution and more a stage performer. For many Indians, Tower Bridge isn't just a London landmark—it's a Bollywood favourite. Scenes from 'Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge' and 'Namastey London' have used the bridge as a backdrop for romance and departure, making it instantly recognisable even to those who've never visited England.
ImageContent.Headline: Mind the gap—this one opens
ImageContent.Title: Tower Bridge, London, England

ImageContent.Description: They don't have brains, bones or even hearts, yet jellyfish have pulsed through Earth's oceans for half a billion years. Their habitats face growing threats from pollution, nutrient-rich runoff and ocean acidification—pressures that make marine conservation essential to restoring coral health and sustaining the species that depend on these waters.
ImageContent.Headline: Just jellin'
ImageContent.Title: Jellyfish swimming in the Pacific, Guerrero, Mexico

ImageContent.Description: Kyoto's Arashiyama district is renowned for its captivating seasonal landscapes. Here, vibrant Japanese maple trees and serene bamboo forests create a harmonious blend of colour and tranquillity. These maples, known for their delicate, deeply lobed leaves, turn fiery shades of red, orange and gold during autumn, attracting visitors from around the world. They are celebrated not only for their beauty but also for their cultural symbolism—representing elegance, peace and the fleeting nature of life.
ImageContent.Headline: Where bamboo breathes and maples blaze
ImageContent.Title: Colourful maple leaves and bamboo forest in Arashiyama, Kyoto, Japan
